awd_titl_txt: CC* Networking Infrastructure: Claflin Research Network
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports Claflin University's research capabilities through a coordinated information technology expansion plan called the "Claflin Research Network". Claflin University is building a 10Gbps Science DMZ supporting Big Data research projects through a re-designed campus border prioritizing science data flows. This new component enables the transfer of very large datasets over long distances in a friction-free path. Claflin's collaborators include the Medical University of South Carolina (MUSC), Clemson University, and many domestic institutions as well as several international institutions. This project greatly increases Claflin's ability to share data between research collaborators in geographically dispersed institutions around the world.

This project will provide Claflin with the ability to be more competitive and makes Claflin a stronger research partner with the innovation ecosystem. In addition, this project allows for greater research and collaboration possibilities for Claflin's undergraduate and graduate student researchers giving them access to data and technology not currently available at our institution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Claflin University built a research network we now call, ?Claflin Research Network?.  The network consists of a network concept called, ?Science Demilitarized Zone (DMZ)? which supports the transfer of very large datasets, provides private and public storage to aid, and support our research effort. This network utilizes an Internet2 connection through a sponsorship with Clemson University Light Rail (CULR) which manages the C-Light network.  This connection allows us to collaborate with all Internet2 connected Higher Education institutions, research companies and other connected entities around the world.  We can now support collaboration with entities who use very large datasets through a friction free network.  Previously, we were blocked because we could not handle the very large datasets and in an efficient way.  We would send large datasets through the United States Post Office or drive them to nearby collaborators.  This severely hindered our capabilities and unnecessarily complicated collaborative efforts.  Now we can simply send or retrieve large files as needed.  In addition, we can update common datasets which update frequently to keep our researchers up to date with the latest research data in their field of study.   

To accommodate the needs of our researchers, we installed a single Data Transfer Node (DTN) whose sole function is to move datasets sent to and received from collaborative institutions. Our design can accommodate additional DTN?s in the future.  To support the DTN device, we also installed a storage device to handle the transferred data.  The capacity of the device is currently 90 Tb of data but can be easily expanded when necessary.  To provide network monitoring and testing, we installed three PerfSONAR devices.  The first one is outside of the Claflin Network to provide test points for connectivity and throughput.  The other two are internal to provide test points for us to test between the two research facilities which are about ? mile apart.  

With this capacity, we can now concentrate on expanding and growing our computational and collaborative efforts with researchers and institutions around the globe.  We are positioned well to provide real-world experiences to give our students a competitive position when applying to graduate schools and when seeking employment in the STEM field.
